remixed_from.title: Side Stackable Component Bins / Louvre Panel Trays

title: Side Stackable Component Bins / Louvre Panel Trays
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-- A lighter derivative of MakeAlot's derivative, with side wall modified, tongue joints height lessened to fit easier, and hook at back removed. Testing of lightness/ strengths of Louvre Boxes to make them lighter and thus cheaper, without compromising strength. Front: Original Louvre design - 31 grams - $1.32
Middle: Hexagonal Wall design - 25 grams - $1.07
Back: Single Wall design - 20 grams - $0.853 This derivative brings the weight down (machine dependent) from 31 grams to 20 grams, shaving off $0.42 for me per box. This is based on Vik's 3mm PLA at $32/ 750 grams. Pic from L - R, Original, Hex test, Single Wall. PS. The original side walls were left intact, as they were only 2 walls thick with a space in between. Also as the side layer is the first layer on the print bed, it coalesces to form a nice solid one piece wall. (Assuming your nozzle sits less then your filament height above your bed.)

This was created as a prop urn or the musical Mary Poppins produced at The Amato Center For The Performing Arts at The Boys and Girls Club of Souhegan Valley. At one point in the show George Banks has drop and break a large urn. It's made of 4 shard types, 8 copies of each. That's 32 shards at 1-2 hours per shard. Each shard type has aligned thread holes that allow the installation of either elastic or monofilament line to hold it into place. We found small dabs of hot glue were just right so it was solid until dropped and broke in a pleasing way. Note, this is a LONG project. During the printing I learned that my extruder motor needed a heatsink. (It took me over 48 hours of printer time)

Notes: Needed to add a heatsink to my extruder motor. The motor was getting so hot that it was softening the filament and it was getting wound around the axle.

title: Astro Tracker for EQ1 mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A tracking device for the old basic EQ1 mount of my 114/900 newtonian telescope.
Parts List:
Amount        Name
1x          Bipolar stepper motor
1x          Arduino Uno or similar
1x          Stepper Driver Pololu A4988 compatible
1x          Potentiometer 10k or similar
1x          Capacitor 100µF, (at least 16V)
1x          605ZZ ball bearing
1x          M5x8 Allen Key screw
1x          M5 washer
2x          M3 Grub screw
2x          M3 Nut
4x             M3x10 Allen Key screw
1x          9 - 12 V battery
1x          EQ1_MountPlate_q3d_RC1.stl
1x          BigGear_41_q3d_RC1.stl
1x          SmallGear_20_q3d_RC1.stl

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

40%

Notes: Gears without Support, the mounting plate could need support depending on your printer.
I recommend 30% or more infill.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/LPN3cEVBJcw" ></iframe>
After Printing make sure the cogwheels catch smoothly. 
Remove the support structure of the plate if you used support for printing.
Tap a M5 thread into the back of the bigger cogwheel. 
Mount the stepper motor onto the flat side of the mounting plate and secure it with 4 M3x10 screws.
Push M3 nuts into the top of each of the cogwheels. Align each M3 Nut with the bore and and add the grubscrews loosely. 
Gently push the small gear onto the stepper motor, sprocket facing the stepper. 
Push the ball bearing into the opening on the other side of the mounting plate. 
Align the bigger gear and join the 605 ball bearing with the bigger gear via the M5x8 bolt, be sure to place a washer between the bearing and the gear part.
Attach the assembly onto the side of your EQ1 mount as seen in the video. There should be a M4 threaded bore for fastening. The shaft of the worm gear should fit into the other side of the bigger cogwheel of the assembly. 
If everything sits well fasten the mounting screws and the grub screws.

The first version just used some spare RepRap hardware I had consisting of a RAMPs board, an Arduino Mega 2560 and a Pololu a4988. The circuit is fairly simple to build on a breadboard or similar (see schematics).
In the video you can see me using a Protoneer cnc shield on a simple Arduino Uno and a 12V fan for cooling. If you're using the cnc shield the stepper driver has to be placed in the X-slot and the 3 jumpers beneath it have to be closed ( -> microstepping x 16 ). The potentiometer can be attached to the "SCL" pin for the signal. ( conveniently 5V and Gnd are just one row down the line) Adjust the Arduino sketch if necessary if you use a different pin assignment.
Designed during winter 2014/15 with Openscad, FreeCAD, Fritzing, Arduino IDE

After considerable time and many failures to make an 'all metal' hot end I caved and changed the design to include a teflon liner. The majority of the design is borrowed from others hot end designs with a few of my tweaks. This is designed for use with a bowden setup and a water cooled block but could work on an air cooled non-bowden setup. Requires a metal lathe but can be a cheap 'mini-lathe' (I used a harbor freight one). Goals are to be reliable, easy to make, easy to service, and not require any really special tools (other than a lathe) Some inspiration from:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,145069,page=1
http://richrap.blogspot.com/2011/08/high-power-hot-end-for-fast-printing.html

The two important parts are the nozzle and 'barrel'. For the nozzle I use brass and for the barrel I use stainless steel. Materials:
--McMasterCarr--
3/8-24 Brass rod (98813A031 $13.04 for 24")
3/8-24 Stainless Steel threaded rod (93250A150 $16.19 for 36")
Brass or aluminum 3/8-24 nuts (92676A455 $5.20 for 10)
3/8" x 3/4" Aluminum bar stock (89215K483 $37.73 for 36")
1/2" delrun or other machinable plastic, with 1/4" ID saves material (1808T12 $3.98 for 12")
1/8" NPT to 1/4" OD quick disconnect tubing fitting (52065K119 $2.24 each)
1/2" OD, 1/4" ID Teflon stock material (8547K23 $3.26 for 12")
--Digikey--
6.8Ohm Power Resistors (RWM06226R80JA15E1 $1.01 for 1)
100K Axial thermister (480-3135-ND $2.47 for 1) Tools:
  • Metal Lathe
  • Center
  • '#77 drill bit (or whatever orifice size you want)
  • 3mm or 1/8" cobalt (or carbide) drill bit
  • 1/4" cobalt (or carbide) drill bit
  • 1/4" sharp tipped (1/4")
  • 5/16" drill bit
  • 3/8" drill bit
  • 1/8" NPT tap
  • 1/4 4 flute end mill (Optional)
    • Machining Nozzle
    Steps:
  • Face one end of bar
  • Create a center divot
  • Drill orifice being VERY careful. Go in ~ 2mm, using small steps
  • Use compound cross feed to taper tip; I like 45 degrees, smooth is best. Make sure there is no divit left
  • Part off the tip leaving some extra length
  • Face new end
  • Create a new center divit
  • Measure length of nozzle and set tailstock at zero with sharp tip flush with end of nozzle
  • Drill in to about 1.5mm less than the length of the nozzle
  • File flats at the nozzle end, don't go too deep!
    • Machining Barrel
    SS I have found to be much better to work with than the cheap low carbon steel from the hardware store
  • Do a rough cut from stock material
  • Face one end and create a divit with a center
  • Drill all the way through with the 1/8" or 3mm drill bit. Take your time and use lots of cutting fluid
  • With the carbide/cobalt 1/4" drill bit drill about 2/3 of the way through. Make sure that the long section end is the side that will interface with the brass nozzle (this avoids a potential mis-match from the 1/8" drill bit wandering).
  • Flip the part around and face the other end
  • Use the carbide/cobalt 1/4" drill bit to drill in until there is a short (~3mm) internal wall with the 1/8" hole through it
  • If you have the 1/4" end mill use it to flatten both sides of the inner wall
  • Use a center or sharp tipped drill bit to chamfer both sides of the inner wall
    • Machining Heater Block
    This should be fairly straight forward, the drawing doesn't leave lots of wiggle room so if doing with hand drill move the holes a little further apart and make the block a little bigger Machining 3/8-24 to 1/8NPT Bowden adapter
    I find tapping with the lathe to be best to keep everything aligned
  • Rough cut a piece of delrun or whatever material you use and face both sides
  • Drill through with a 5/16 drill bit
  • Tap one side to 3/8-24
  • Tap the other side to 1/8 NPT be sure to go in to the end of the tap
    • Modifying NPT push fit connector
    Use a lathe to drill out the threaded end as it is easy to go too far with a hand drill Teflon liner
  • Use a file to taper one end
  • Do a rough fit of the piece with just the nozzle and barrier and cut the the liner until there is just a short gap between the nozzle and barrier
    • Misc
  • Wrap the leads from the thermister and power resistors with kapton tape before assembly
  • Thread the barrel into the heater block then use the nozzle to tighten them together
  • I like to thin out one of the brass/aluminum nuts to use for the cold end attachment and taper another to go near the nozzle tip (optional)
  • Pictures show 3/8-16 which works fine; I switched to 3/8-24 to have more threads in the heater block and allow finer height adjustment
  • Be very careful that the thermister and heater wires don't touch. The heaters are kept at +12V (switches -) I have fried at least one mega A-D converter when a thermister got a 12V load on it!

title: Moen 1417 Roman Tub Hand Shower Elbow insert

description.text:
This is a replacement plastic insert to the Moen 1417BN. Mine broke after I dropped something on the hand shower head and it snapped off, but don't tell the wife that. To my horror, the list replacement price for the whole elbow is a whopping $65. To remove the old plastic insert, I ended up drilling it out until it. There are 2 additional pieces to the assembly, a plastic retaining clip (like a letter C) and a #9 o-ring (5/8" OD x 7/16" ID x 3/32). Be careful not to destroy the retaining ring, but you can simply buy a new O-ring if needed. There are 2 metal pieces to the assembly, the elbow with male threads, and the stem with female threads. Once the old parts are disassembled and the new part is printed, you are ready to begin.

  • Slide the printed part through the stem (the smaller metal piece). The flanged portion will rest inside the stem. Add the straining mesh washer to the stem to keep the printed part in place.

  • Put the O-ring onto the printed part. It fits into the groove near the center of the part.

  • Put the old plastic retaining clip on the lower groove.

  • Be warned, once you slide the part in and the clip engages, it will be non-removable.

  • Press the part into the elbow. It will take a bit of force to squeeze it past the o-ring. You should hear a click when the retaining clip engages. If done right, the piece should look as good as new.
    • While functional, keep in mind that the new 3d printed part is not as strong as the injection molded part it is replacing. But, you can always fix it for pennies. So you'll come out ahead assuming you don't replace it 50+ times.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I printed this at .2 @ 100% for maximum strength. I included the sketchup files. I rounded the interior corners to assist a bit in air printing. I included the sketchup file for both pre and post rounding just in case you need to edit the file. You'll see there's a flat part to the flange. Print the insert with that side down so the piece is lateral on the print table. This way it doesn't snap off as easy.

comments.text: So I have come to the conclusion that PLA just isn't strong enough. It ended up snapping off under it's own weight over a week or so. ABS maybe, but PLA no.

Relive that sunny Saturday romping at the dog park with this simple, colorful neighborhood scene lasercut from foamcore. This piece is one of several vignette designed around Inventor Studio's Lasercut Foamcore Scenes, a simple interlocking geometry system for foamcore. Like this scene, but want one with other dogs? Maybe what's missing is a play structure for the kids. Design additional elements yourself using the included interlocking base shape and make this scene your own. Teachers might consider using this interlocking system in makerspaces and other project-based classroom learning environments. Other designs released so far in this series can be found here, here, and here. Wipe your feet before you come back indoors.

Lasercutting & Assembly Instructions An SVG file has been included for each color used in this design, and 2 separate cuts for green. Cutting the pieces on your laser should be very straightforward if you've cut foamcore before. Multi-pass cuts using reduced power are recommended, because this reduces the amount of foam shrinkage. Some layers in this design involve gluing different colored pieces onto the base part. Look carefully at the photo, paying attention to whether the additional pieces are glued in front or in back of the base piece. Inexpensive bailing wire and painters tape are used to attach hanging elements of the scene.

Designed Using Inkscape & Tinkercad Inventor Studios' Lasercut Foamcore Scenes are designed using Tinkercad and Inkscape. You can either edit the Inkscape SVG files found in this Thing directly or import them into Tinkercad to make modifications to this scene or create wholly new scenes for yourself, for classroom instruction, and to share with others.

This are single-plate build versions of e-NABLE's Raptor Reloaded, optimised for the Ultimaker 2 (and any other FFF printer with a square build plate). This model is scaled at 100%, and can be scaled up to 150% on the UM2.
UPDATED 29 January 2016:  In response to some requests, I've added pre-scaled versions at 100 to 150%.  The original files and the 100% files are identical.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

35%

Notes: Best printed in PLA with 2 shells (0.8mm based on 0.4mm nozzle diameter). Quality and strength will be greatly enhanced by a fairly slow print speed — 40-50 mm/s is recommended. Do not add any supports — the design has all needed supports and allowing your slicer to add more will most likely block the hollow line runs critical to proper operation. The settings above will result in a full print time of about 14 hours on a UM2. Scaling up to 150% takes approximately 40 hours per print.

I'm using a DLink DCS-930LB camera as a printer monitor and needed a camera mount to fit on the side of an Ultimaker 2 Extended (should work for the regular one too). This was inspired by "Add-on Dlink camera bracket for Replicator 2X (2)" by @davedelay [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:325121], which btw works great for my Relicator 2X. I've uploaded both .stl file and .igs file (if you want to remix) - I designed this model in Fusion 360.

Modifying an STL file isn't a walk in the park (for me at least), but I didn't want to recreate the thread part of the mount, so I cut off the thread part from the "Prusa i3 - Dlink Camera Mount" by @dtwrv6 and imported it into Fusion 360 as a mesh body. 
Unfortunately it was still too many polygons, so I couldn't convert from mesh to brep body - which is why the thread piece is separate from the bracket here (If you know a good way to combine a mesh to a body in Fusion 360 or other app, let me know.) 
I settled for printing both parts and gluing them together with ABS cement (super glue should work fine too).

2015-09-25: dlink_camera_bracket_ultimaker2_v10.stl I realized that I needed the camera a little higher up to view above the build plate in the early stages of a print. Also, I extended the bracket frame out 20mm to give the camera a wider view. The problem with the Ultimaker 2 Extended is that the printer is much taller than the standard, so the camera doesn't have wide enough of an angle to view the top of the build plate at the start and after the print is complete and the plate rests down at the bottom. I suppose I could try attaching one of those smartphone fish-eye/wide-angle lenses to the DLink.

The dual of the rhombicosidodecahedron has 60 identical faces shaped like kites.  As it has 3 different types of vertices it would result in a 60 sided dice with a bias towards some numbers.  However by numbering the faces to make the vertices sharing 3 faces all identical, (icosihedral dice), or the faces sharing 5 vertices all identical, (dodecahedral dice), certaintly some, possibly all, of the bias is removed.  OpenSCAD code is included.

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes: The dice are large, about 65 mm in diameter, to make it easier to see which face
is uppermost. The faces were scraped to remove excess plastic. For 6's and 9's the top of the kite is "up" and the tail is "down".

comments.text:
Evidently the number of faces meeting at a vertex has nothing to do with whether a die is "fair" or not -
see http://loki3.com/poly/fair-dice.html - an article about what makes dice "fair". The die given here - a deltoidal hexecontahedron - is an isohedron - that is any face can be mapped to another by a rotation or reflection.

This design has been replaced with the improved SkyTrak Lite, found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1471256 This multirotor design is intended as a framework, rather than a finalized product. I had the ideal of building an airframe on tracks (like a camera rig) rather than on plates like most designs out there. Cutting carbon fiber plates for a custom UAV is complicated and laborious. 3D printed multirotor airframes do not scale up well because plastic is too flexible. The SkyTrak solves both issues by building a UAV on a carbon fiber tube "backbone". The tubes are light weight, common and cheap. The 3D printed plastic parts simply serve as joints. Tubes are 10mm diameter, spaced 60mm from center to center, I chose this format because it is a common rail configuration used on some commercial airframes and gimbals, like Tarot and DYS. As an added bonus, this design philosophy makes the SkyTrak fully modular and customizable. You can create your own parts and attach them anywhere on the tracks. It's also easy to repair of modify. I have designed the SkyTrak so that any part can be removed without having to do a full tear-down. Furthermore, I have invented an arm-folding mechanism that works better than most common clips or friction methods found in regular commercial airframes. I have been shooting aerial video with this aircraft for a week and I am very pleased with it. That being said, this first prototype has a few flaws. It's too heavy for my taste. At around 550 g, it's heavier than the TBS Discovery (415 g). I also want to reduce the number of plastic parts. I'm currently working on an improved design: the SkyTrak Lite... Coming soon! ASSEMBLY - I have included pictures that should help you understand how it's put together. Here is a list of the parts you will need to buy. Make sure that your rail tubes have a 1 mm wall thickness. The 0.5 mm ones are too fragile. PARTS - For the motor mounts, I used iFlight universal motor mounts (http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-Tarot-M16-Flight-Seat-Motor-Mount-Orange-TL68B08-01-multicopter-multirotor-frame-kit-quadcopter/32315808262.html) but anything that clamps to a 16mm diameter tube will work. *SkyTrak_arm_mount.stl: 4x CF tube 10x8x500mm (cut them to the desired length) | 8x M3 18mm socket screw | 8x M3 lock nuts | 4x M4 35mm socket screw | 4x M4 lock nuts | 8x 8/4mm washer | 4x 9/4.5mm washer *SkyTrak_arm_clamp_rear.STL and SkyTrak_arm_clamp_front.STL: 4x CF tube 16x14x180mm (or longer) | 4x M3 28mm socket screw | 4x M3 lock nuts *SkyTrak_leg_mount_bottom.STL: 4x M3 12mm socket screw | 4x M3 nuts *SkyTrak_GPS_mount_top.STL: 2x M3 12mm socket screw | 2x M3 nuts SkyTrak_normal_component_plate.STL and SkyTrak_extra_component_plate.STL: 4x 28mm stand-off | 12x M3 8mm socket screw | 4x M3 nuts | 8x 8/4mm washer

Reduce the solid infill threshold area if the slicer creates too much solid infill. My prototype was printed with PLA.

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment.
I thought about that during the early design phase, but keeping the arm mounts close to the rails is a intentional decision.
Three reasons:
1- If I made one of the mounts wider, it would be bigger and therefore heavier. I would also have to make it ticker to compensate for the plastic's natural flexibility, further increasing the weight.
2- My design philosophy is to have as few distinct parts as possible. So having identical front and rear mounts was preferable.

Make your good old Thing-O-Matic truly automatic! Here is mine at the Seattle Mini Makerfaire last weekend churning out bracelets: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nmmUECyz-ek
Both of my machines printed continuously both days without any major breakdowns, my TOM giving away ~70 bracelets and my Rep1 ~60 bearings. Since switching to PLA, I hadn't been using my Automated Build Platform, since it doesn't stick so well to the old kapton belt. However, I finally went through and fixed up the design, and it now works better than ever.

First, take a look at the ancestor, Truly Automatic Thing-O-Matic. Those instructions still apply. I've included a sturdier version of gaerisl's belt tensioner because my old one was warping pretty badly under the strain of keeping the belt taught. It requires a couple of M3x20 screws and nuts, but it goes on the same way.   
To make the belt, cover a piece of paper (I use the cover of a magazine, because it's thin, strong and long enough for the belt) with kapton tape on both sides (to make it tough). Then cover one side with blue tape (blue tape sticks better to kapton than anything else). Then cut the belt out of this tape-paper, using the original belt shape as a template.   
Print out the belt mould (I use zero infill with 4 perimeters for strength).  Then wrap the belt around the mould and tape the seam with 3/4" kapton tape. Make sure the belt is uniformly tight so that it's a true cylinder. There will be a small gap you tape over (~3mm). Slide the belt off the mould and tape the inside of the gap as well. Fold the tape over the sides to make sure it won't peel.   
Assemble everything as with the previous version's instructions and tighten up the belt until it rides flat. I find that even though PLA doesn't stick as well to kapton, it will usually still work even if the seam is under the print, since it's narrow.   
I set the heated bed to 35C, mostly because it does something to the blue tape glue that makes it adhere to the kapton really well. This belt won't resist parts warping, so I recommend switching out to the heated build platform for more precise prints (hence the swappable build plate mod is extremely useful).

comments.text: Any ideas on how to make an ABP for the Rep2? May be more difficult with the vertical moving platform.  I was thinking of a spring-loaded conveyor belt tensioner that would not restrict platform movement yet remain flat enough to build on reliably.
comments.author: seg9585

comments.text: Actually, it's probably easier with a platform that only moves in one direction. The hard part is the size, which will require that much more tension to keep the belt flat. I would recommend making small overlaps for the belt to slide under; that would help keep the free sides from curling up as a print shrinks. I can't wait to see what you come up with.

A stylized push plane with spinning propeller. It's grandkids week at our household so I designed and printed an airplane push toy as an addition to the butterfly push toy (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1027577). Our Makerbot Replicator 2 is running overtime printing these things in a variety of color combinations. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pKn8SvAMDXQ. All pieces are printed with the exception of the wide rubber bands used for traction. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: 2 shells

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.
Place wide rubber bands around the circumference of each wheel for traction.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
A small dot of cyanoacrylate inside the appropriate holes hold the wing and chassis pins to the wings and chassis respectively.  Small dots may also assist in holding the fuselage sections together.
Apply a small amount of light machine oil to the axle and gear surfaces.
Comment if you have questions.

author: fabioderossi

description.text:
I'm trying to make a mind controlled tentacle and this is where I'm at so far.
Right now, the ball and socket joints are a little too loose, and the movement isn't very good (partly due to the weight of the parts).
Also the sockets are a little stiff and fragile when printed with PLA
Once all that is sorted, I'll hook it up to some servos and the obligatory Arduino.
Video of it "working": http://youtu.be/EVMatHNgC6s
Print one end and as many segments as you want. Break off the supports on the segments. String some cord through the holes. You need a minimum of 3.

comments.text: Personally, I think being able to control it with some sort of connected hand device would be pretty cool (not to mention easier). maybe that'd be a good starting point.
comments.author: Clawsome

comments.text: Wow, this project has a lot of potential and is very interesting. If anything you could put a control system by adding a base with the an Arduino and a few stepper motors to control the system.
comments.author: Bakguf

comments.text: The base would pretty much act as the brains of the entire system and would essential control the mechanical tentacle, I don't know how strong the tentacle would be though.
comments.author: Bakguf

comments.text: I think that I am going to try printing a few of these and mounting them on my respirator. Then run some little cables to a neck piece. Its not mind control but it should be hands free puppetry. What do you think?
comments.author: Totemecha

comments.text: By any chance, have you done this project? I would be interested in a picture or two :)
comments.author: Totemecha

comments.text: I wonder if adding soft springs in between the joints would give more fine control.
comments.author: black_light_st

comments.text:
i wonder if ninjaflex would help cut down on weight and maybe give you more of a flexible joint.
awesome concept btw
comments.author: SkwidMan

comments.text: You could axe the plastic ball and shaft of the ball joint and mount ball bearings on a short piece of threaded rod screwed into the base of each one. You would need to drill and tap each ball bearing to the size of your threaded rod (M4 or M5 perhaps) or just drill and super glue, and find a ball bearing to match the inside size of the cup would be sweet as... I would like to try this and post results as I have plenty of ball bearings, cheers!!

author: Studio

description.text:
This is a kit for printing your own spud-tastic, wearable, DEVO Energy Dome! I CAD designed it as close to the original I could from pictures and measurements taken from an actual DEVO dome. This is a recent re-design on my part to make it a little easier to print and assemble. Comment with questions!
Note- I do not own any right to the DEVO Energy Dome, this is just fan art.
Assembly I assembled it with some Cyanoacrylate glue. It doesn't need sanding. I used a model filler to hide the seems and then spray painted it for the glossy finish.

I imported a picture of a dome and tried to trace it as close as I could while taking into account other measurements and reference, along with personal judgement for proportions. I then revolved the sketch and then extruded the supports that hold it together.

title: iPhone 6 and 6 Plus Garmin Mount for Indoor Training

description.text:
I designed this for indoor use on a trainer or rollers with an app like Zwift, Trainer Road, etc. I wouldn't recommend it for outdoor road rides. The design is simple to make it as easy to print as possible.
Please slide the iPhone into the holder from the bottom. If you do it the opposite you'll find the protruding camera lens in the way. 
The mount itself it snugger than a normal Garmin so spend a second aligning one end and then push the whole mount down and then twist firmly. 
I haven't tried it with the iPhone 6s or iPhone 6s Plus but based on Apple's size description on their website it should be close enough to work. 
For longer rides or ones where you're out of the saddle a lot, I'd recommend wrapping it in plastic wrap or a zip lock to stop the sweat damaging the iPhone.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium or Higher

Notes: If your printer needs supports I recommend using the "iPhone6Plus_Garmin_Mount_supports.stl" file and printing it vertically with a Raft. Theirs a photo showing my setup above. The supports should be easy to pick off. I'd also recommend printing at a medium or high setting so the mount accurately connects and is strong enough not to break off after repetitive use.

title: Universal Camera Adapter for telescopes, microscopes, digiscoping or afocal photography

description.text: Right now is completely functional and tested with 1.25" oculars. The second pic was taken using a celestron nextar SE 8 and a small sony camera Qx-10, in the last super moon eclipse in September 27 2015 :), all pictures are mine. Works really well. My girlfriend and I used tinkercad to design it: Main part thumb wheel 1 thumb wheel 2 To assemble it, use: 3 1/4 inch nut And 3 bolts: 1- 1/4(d) X 1/2(long) inch bolt. For the camera. 1- 1/4(d) X 1 1/2(long) inch bolt. To place the adapter in the telescope. 1- 1/4 X 1 1/2(long) inch bolt. To link both parts.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10% 3D honeycomb+15% 3D honeycomb

Notes: All parts are in the same file, but personally, I print the camera base (the higher thing where is placed the camera) using a personal setting in slic3r, to infill areas of less than 20mm^2 . and 15% infill. all other parts use 10% infill. I use blue t-glase to print the main body and blue glow PLA to print the other parts (I like that my telescope parts glow in the dark :P)

Steps Just follow the image sequence and you will be fine. The small squared thumb wheel is to protect the link of both parts. And the biggest one is to be used to mantain the bolt of the camera in place when not used, and in case of a failure in the bolt that fix the ocular. e.g see figure 6. See the last figure for an idea to storage.

author: bfsc

description.text:
This 3D-printable plastic bag holder works by clamping the edge of a plastic bag onto a wall-mounted plate. The two parts (plate and wedge) are designed with round surfaces to avoid damage to the plastic bag. The wedge makes sure that the heavier the bag gets, the stronger it grips, but is at the same time very easy to remove. To support larger bags, several holders can be mounted on a wall side-by-side or i.e. in a 90 degree corner between two walls. Check out the video below:
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=douYpEH3t0g
  • http://geekubator.org/3d-printable-plastic-bag-holder/

Please follow these steps:
  • Download the STL files below
  • Print them on your 3D printer
  • Mount them with four small screws on a flat wall surface
  • Hang your plastic garbage bag
  • Enjoy the fruits of free open hardware design! :)

Aratro rovesciatore ordinario (aratro a versoio). Il versoio o orecchio o rovesciatoio è uno degli organi lavoranti dell'aratro, responsabile del ribaltamento laterale della fetta tagliata e sollevata dal vomere. Questo tipo di aratro permetteva di ribaltare la terra sempre nello stesso verso indipendentemente da come veniva percorso il campo.
Tipper ordinary plow (moldboard plow). The moldboard or ear or tool overthrow is one of the working parts of the plow, in charge of the side tilting of the slice cut and raised by the plow. This type of plow allowed to overturn the earth in the same direction regardless of how was the path field.

This simple holder helps me to see the cellphone screen simuntanisly and also to intract with it without the need to leave the keyboard or to look away. Other phones may need to scale the stl .
Also diffrent laptop may need different thickness parameters

description.text: Beetle man! Taking the concept of a centaur, this is a man fused with a beetle in order to create a powerful creature of the under-depths. Yes

Resolution:

Notes: Print with full supports. 10% infill should be sufficient. He has some fine details so I would recommend the lowest resolution possible, he should be able to have a good print using 2mm layer height. I just finished creating him and will be working on splitting the model to print in halves, and will maybe remove the legs and make those separate prints so he can print support-less for higher quality.

print_settings.Notes:: Lower ball joint screw hole was chased with a 9/64 bit, then use a M4X0.7 tap to create threads and threaded in.

title: Hobby King Rattler 1/8 Buggy lower Arm

description.text:
Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:
  • Shock and suspension shaft retainer screws were chased with a 5/64 drill bit.
  • Suspension shaft was chased with a 1/8 drill bit and then suspension shaft was used to finish it up. Once shaft is through both ends. left it run for a bit at full speed. this will heat up the shaft and widen the hole perfectly. remove it and allow parts to cool down.
  • Lower ball joint screw hole was chased with a 9/64 bit, then use a M4X0.7 tap to create threads and threaded in.

remixed_from.author: zapta
remixed_from.title: Gerry Sweeney's Seven Decade Programmable Resistor Box

title: Case for Seven Decade Programmable Resistor Board

description.text: This is an adaptation of zapta's Gerry Sweeney's Seven Decade Programmable Resistor Box, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:521303. The remix adapts the design for use with a different China-sourced seven decade programmable resistor board available on eBay. These boards are approximately 65 by 90 mm in size. The board listing titles include the text "1R 9999999R Seven Decade Programmable Resistor Board Step 1R". I was initially planning on building a switch-based decade box, but for $9.98 USD total cash outlay I couldn't resist purchasing one of these boards. In addition to dimensional changes for the different board and size of corner screws, the remix also uses the MCAD library polyhole function for improved dimensional control of the corner screw mounting holes. Various improvements have been made regarding geometry overlap in order to provide a cleaner preview in openSCAD and to minimize any mesh issues in the design. Additional revision notes are provided in the openSCAD source.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: The test print was generated on an 8-inch MakerFarm i3v customized with Smoothieboard and an e3dv6 hot end with 0.40mm nozzle. Simplify3D slicer settings included 0.20mm layer height, 2 perimeters, 2 solid top and bottom layers, 20% rectilinear infill, no support, and a print speed of 80 mm/sec. I used Voltivo Excelfil 1.75mm Cool Black PLA filament at a hot end temperature of 215 degrees C, printing onto a hair-spray coated glass bed set to 55 degrees C for the first layer and 50 degrees after the first layer. No additional print cooling or minimum layer time constraints were applied. Simplify3D estimates include 5.8m of filament being required and a print time of 55 minutes.

Remove the corner screws and standoffs from the eBay board, saving the M2 screws for reuse. 
Slightly bend the solder tabs on the resistor board banana jacks up so that they clear the edge of the programmable resistor board. This will ensure they clear the raised outer edge of the box after board installation.  
Place the resistor board in the recess of the printed box and thread the four M2 screws removed earlier into the corner holes.  
Add self-adhesive rubber bumpers to the bottom of the box as desired.

comments.text: One more demo video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NXAhOEn8nXQ
comments.author: zapta

comments.text: Looks very nice. One thing you may want to consider is using a metal threaded insert for the four screws.
comments.author: zapta

comments.text: The inserts are a slick idea. I'll have to keep them in mind for other projects.  However, I had no problem threading the M2 x 4mm screws from the resistor board standoffs directly into the printed holes.  That's likely due to using the polyhole method for the hole design and the fact that the 4mm screws only need to have a thread engagement of about 2.4mm.  Those that want to modify the design to use the inserts are certainly welcome to do so. Bear in mind that the resistor board ships with M2 screws. The example link zapta provided is for an M2.5 insert.  If those are used, you'll need M2.5 screws and will need to enlarge the holes in the board slightly in order to accommodate them.

Hello.
thank you for your opinion.
Probably your thought is right.
The accuracy of the clock is decided by the length of the string.
The adjustment mechanism of that purpose may be necessary.
I glue the string together in a scotch tape on the swing arm. So I can easily regulate the length of the string.
As a result, I decide timing at the weight of the weight. It lets the volume of the water in the plastic bottle increase and decrease and performs it.
This is because a gravity moment delicately influences it.
Continuously operating it is difficult, and time may be still out of order more than one hour for 24 hours.

author: DanielHC

title: Samsung Galaxy S3 with Lifeproof Car Mount

description.text:
I wanted a car mount for my phone that would allow me to plug it into the stereo to listen to podcasts while driving, and also allow me to charge it. The problem was, I also have a Lifeproof case on it, so I had to design a mount that would fit my phone and its case.
So far I have a rough model for the main part that holds the phone and allows for use of most of the screen, while allowing the charging port and cover to be clear. I may have gone a little overboard rounding all the corners though.
Next I will be working on the actual part that mounts it into the car. I haven't decided if I will make it so it will clip into the vents, or jam into the space above the radio where it holds CDs. Tune in to find out.

Part of the effort to clean up the profile of the machine for enclosing it.  There are other nice options for holding the filament that do away with the pivoting arm entirely.  This one keeps the arm and uses it, but changes the orientation.

title: Ultimaker V2: Modified Z-axis Aluminum Plate for MK2B Heatbed

description.text: These are the .ipt & .dxf files of the aluminum plate that the UItimaker V2 uses for the Z-axis, with the additional holes added in to make it compatible with this kit here (http://www.ebay.com/itm/Anodized-Aluminum-Heated-Bed-Buld-Plate-for-3D-Printer-RepRap-Prusa-Makerbot-/321336349749?var=&hash=item4ad1239435) However, any MK2B heatbed should mount without any issues, as long as there is 209mm between each hole. You might ask: what is the point of this? Isn't there an official Ultimaker kit?!? Good question. The biggest reason I'm doing this is cost. I could spend roughly ~$150 for the official aluminum plate and heat bed alone, or I could re-use my existing heat bed & buy a piece of aluminum stock for $10 and have it cut using my University's water jet. Since it both saves me money and lets me play with high-power equipment, it's a win-win! It should also be noted that this has the holes for the original UM2 Heatbed as well. So if you ever do want to upgrade down the road to the official UM2 heatbed for the little bit of extra build area it gives you, it's easily doable. Please ask any questions in the comments, and make sure you check out jasonatepaint's awesome Aluminum Extrusion UM2. I'm excited to finally be able to have an Ultimaker!

title: RWG Filament Cooler modified with OpenSCAD (DOES NOT WORK WELL)

description.text:
This is a modification of the RWG Filament cooler using OpenSCAD.
Thanks to Russ Gries for the cooler design.
As I can not print vertically, I decided to modify the cooler to print horizontally in 2 parts.
I modified this part for Lyman Filament Extruder v5 that I am customizing for my build.
I used slic3r to split the parts into two, hence the adjustments.
After downloading the scad files, you will have to modify the location of the STL files to edit them.
I added 3mm holes to screw this cooler in place while attaching a larger fan using the following adapter.
To make custom adapter for any fan size, use this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735038
I have modified and used the fan plate from this thing's scad file. For now, I just made the fan plate mount sufficient for an adapter. However it can be modified to actually fit a 40 or 50 mm fan. CAUTION: Print with full support. Printing with ABS will warp the unsupported part, so watch out for the extruder fan & mount if you have one. HINT: Flip it to print it might be a better idea for this model. I already tried and failed 2 times trying to print it upright. So uploaded the flipped file. Dimensions for making your custom adapter to fit the fan plate:
fanPlateDia=33;
fanPlateDistanceBetweenScrews=28;
fanplateWallThickness=10.0;
fanPlateScrewDia=3.4;

comments.text:
Please do not use a 12 mm fan for this item. It does not generate sufficient air flow for it to work.
A 12V blower is the best option for this model.

title: Raspberry Pi Touch Display Wall Bracket

description.text: A bracket to mount the official Raspberry Pi touch display to the wall. Originally designed as one piece, but it doesn't fit on my Lulzbot Mini that way, so I split it up. It might be better this way. Here's the Fusion 360 project: http://a360.co/1QDItpT
I designed this in Autodesk Fusion 360.  I downloaded some models of the screen and Raspberry Pi found elsewhere, connected them together with standoffs and joints, and built the frame around them.

comments.text: Where did you download the touchscreen model from? I'm trying to find one myself.

comments.text: I designed the slots in it specifically to hold the official touch display.  I don't know what screens you're referring to, but it's unlikely that they'd have the same bezel.
